speaker: Elena
text: The article's title is 'Time To Give Up On Predicting Climate Change?' That sounds like giving up entirely, doesn't it?

speaker: James
text: [dry] More like giving up on a specific *type* of prediction: that we can collectively prevent it. Cassandra was right, after all.

speaker: Elena
text: But history also shows societies reacting to existential threats. We don't just roll over.

speaker: James
text: Or they collapse. Rome didn't 'react' its way out of the Goths.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a bit reductive. Look at the rapid shift in renewable energy. The 'renewables and battery revolution' article highlights significant progress.

speaker: James
text: [clipped] Progress at what scale, Elena? Emissions are still rising globally. That's the inconvenient truth.

speaker: Elena
text: Not everywhere. Many European utilities, facing an 'existential crisis,' are adapting fast. Denmark's emissions are significantly down.

speaker: James
text: Denmark is a small, wealthy nation. What about China? India? The global South?

speaker: Elena
text: So we just abandon them? The article suggests national self-interest, but climate change doesn't respect borders.

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] It doesn't, but national governments *do*. They'll protect their own when resources become scarce. Look at the data on food security.

speaker: Elena
text: The 'Impact Of Food' article argues for *managing* the new reality. That's not giving up on solutions, just prevention.

speaker: James
text: But managing for *whom*? For *your* country first. The article is clear: international law won't hold.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a stretch. The UN might creak, but a total collapse of international institutions?

speaker: James
text: When you have millions of climate refugees and resource wars, tell me how well the Security Council will function.

speaker: Elena
text: But the IPCC reports still talk about global cooperation as essential.

speaker: James
text: They *hope* for it. Cassandra *hoped* too. We've already baked in 1.6 degrees of warming.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, the 1.6°C figure is grim. But that's precisely why we need *more* collective effort, not less.

speaker: James
text: [sardonic] And how's that working out? Since the Rio conference in '92, global emissions have gone up. Dramatically.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a fair point about the aggregate. But look at private investment in green tech. It's exploded.

speaker: James
text: Investment doesn't equal sufficient action. It just means some people see a profit. The system adapts, but not in time.

speaker: Elena
text: But it *creates* options for resilience. Vertical farming, for instance, mentioned as part of 'electrical convergence power, transport and agriculture'.

speaker: James
text: Which, again, helps *local* populations. It reinforces the national focus. Self-sufficiency.

speaker: Elena
text: [thoughtful] I see your point there. If international cooperation fails, then local and national resilience *becomes* the global strategy.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. It's not giving up, it's shifting focus to what's actually achievable when grand political solutions aren't.

speaker: Elena
text: But what about the *moral* argument? The site has an article titled 'The immorality of climate change'.

speaker: James
text: [dry] Morality rarely dictates geopolitics when national survival is on the line. Self-interest is a far stronger driver.

speaker: Elena
text: So you're saying the wealthy nations, who contributed most, should just wall themselves off?

speaker: James
text: I'm saying they *will*. Not 'should'. The evidence of history supports this when resources dwindle.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, I'll concede that historical precedent often points to self-preservation during crises. It's hard to argue against that.

speaker: James
text: Good. Because the alternative is hoping for an international consensus that has consistently failed for decades.

speaker: Elena
text: But isn't there still a role for shared scientific knowledge? Even if countries act nationally, they still need the best data.

speaker: James
text: Absolutely. Intelligence sharing, scientific collaboration on adaptation strategies – that will continue. It's practical.

speaker: Elena
text: So it's not a complete retreat into isolation. More a shift from *preventative* global governance to *adaptive* global information sharing.

speaker: James
text: [conceding] That's a nuanced way to put it. And I think that's a key distinction.

speaker: Elena
text: It still feels... grim. That Cassandra was right about the disbelief, and now we face the consequences.

speaker: James
text: She was. But her insanity came from *not being believed*. We believe the science now. We just can't *act* globally.

speaker: Elena
text: So the challenge isn't belief, it's collective political will in a fragmented world.

speaker: James
text: Always has been. The difference is the stakes are now existential.

speaker: Elena
text: And the data. The data means we can't pretend we don't know what's coming.

speaker: James
text: No. We cannot.
